Dear Roman Kolodchin:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• Be signed and dated.
A six-month provisional license is recommended. You must contest or agree to the
issuance of a provisional license in writing, on the CWL-4617 within 15 days, with
submission of the corrective action plan. If you do not submit the CWL-4617, it will be
treated as contested. Even if you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must
still submit an acceptable corrective action plan.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Cassandra Thomas, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4116
Section (2) An institution's chief administrator shall be administratively
Description responsible annually for all of the following functions: (b) Develop
and implement a written plan to correct, within 6 months, rule
violations identified as a result of the assessment conducted
pursuant to subdivision (a) of this subrule.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Allegation 1:
Facility has outstanding CAPs with the earliest being due in June
2024 and despite efforts to assist the CA/LD in getting access to
CWLM he still has not submitted a DSA request.
Allegation 2:
While verifying the facility’s compliance with their 2024 Interim
CAP it was discovered the CAP had not been implemented and
the facility was still in non-compliance with the rule cited in the
2024 Interim Inspection.
Investigation Allegation 1:
Interviews:
On 01/09/2025 an onsite visit was made to Safehaus Too. An
interview was completed with Chief Administrator. He was
advised that an investigation was being initiated due to his failure
to submit approved corrective action plans in CWLM. It was
confirmed that Safehuas Too had pending corrective action plans
for 2024 Interim, Special Investigation #2024SIC0001412, Special
Investigation #2024SIC0000017 and Special Investigation
#2024SIC0001573. Chief Administrator reported that he has been
attempting to gain access to CWLM without success. Contact
information of CWLM specialist was provided to Chief
Administrator for more specialized assistance.
On 01/14/2025 an email was sent to Chief Administrator
requesting an update. He responded and advised that he had
participated in a meeting with CWLM Specialist and had a few
additional steps to complete before he gained access.
On 01/21/2025 a video conference was held with Chief
Administrator and CWLM Specialist to troubleshoot issues
associated with Chief Administrator obtaining CWLM access.
2

On 01/21/2025 an email was sent to CWLM Specialist and Chief
Administrator requesting an update on access to CWLM. He
responded and advised that all tasks and approvals have been
completed, and his agency is ready for the next steps.
On 02/07/2025 an onsite visit was made to Safehaus. Chief
Administrator was interviewed and an update on CWLM access
was requested. He advised that both he and the Program
Manager have CWLM access and will be able to enter the
corrective action plans soon. I requested for Chief Administrator
or Program Manager to log in and show that they have access,
and neither was able to log into CWLM. Chief Administrator
documented passwords and computer issues as the reason.
On 02/12/2025 an email was sent to Chief Administrator and
CWLM Specialist. Chief Administrator was advised that a
discussion was had with the CWLM Specialist regarding agency
access to CWLM. After reviewing the system, it was documented
that the agency still does not have the proper access.
Specifically, the user group status that was selected was incorrect
and he would need to resubmit his request and make the proper
selection for the user group type.
As of 03/04/2025 it was confirmed by review of CWLM that
corrective action plans for Safehaus Too 2024 Interim, Special
Investigation #2024SIC0001412, Special Investigation
#2024SIC0000017 and Special Investigation #2024SIC0001573
had not been entered into CWLM.
Documents Reviewed:
Special Investigation #2024SIC0001573 – Report highlighted
non-compliance by the agency and the recommendation indicated
a corrective action plan is required. Corrective Action Plan was
due 10/16/2024.
Special Investigation #2024SIC0001412 – Report highlighted
non-compliance by the agency and the recommendation indicated
a corrective action plan is required. Corrective Action Plan was
due 06/28/2024.
Special Investigation #2024SIC0000017 – Report highlighted
non-compliance by the agency and the recommendation indicated
a corrective action plan is required.
Safehaus Too 2024 Interim – Report highlighted non-compliance
by the agency and the recommendation indicated a corrective
3

action plan is required with a license change to a first provisional
license was recommended. The Corrective Action Plan was due
02/05/2025.
E-mail correspondence:
On 5/6/2024 an e-mail went out to all Chief Administrators from the
Director of DCWL informing them of the upcoming change for
corrective action plans to be entered into CWLM.
E-mail correspondence occurred on 5/14/24, 7/8/24, 9/20/24,
11/13/24, 12/2/24, 1/7/25, to CA, from Area Manager, Consultant,
and/or the CWLM Help desk regarding assistance in getting access
to CWLM. The CA was provided with Business Processes and
training videos on 10/04/2024.
Outlook Calendar Invitation – Chief Administrator was invited to
attend one of four meetings with MDHHS to review how obtain
access in CWLM, held on 10/08/2024 and 10/10/2024. He was also
invited to a corrective action plan overview training held on
11/04/2024, hosted by MDHHS to provide additional training to
Chief Administrators on how to enter corrective action plans in
CWLM after gaining access to the system.
Allegation 2:
DCWL Consultant was present at Safehaus Too on 12/04/2024,
01/09/2025, 02/07/2025, 03/07/2025 and 04/04/2025. During each
unannounced visit, it was documented that the agency had failed to
complete and implement all terms of the Corrective Action Plan for
the 2024 Interim. To date, the agency still has not submitted a copy
of the 2022, 2023 or 2024 financial audit.
Documents Reviewed
Safehaus 2024 Interim Audit report documented that the agency
was in non-compliance with licensing rule CCI Rule 400.4108 and
a corrective action plan is required.
Analysis Allegation 1:
At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in non-compliance with licensing rule 4116-2-b. The Chief
Administrator failed to complete and submit a timely corrective
action plan via CWLM.
Allegation 2:
At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in non-compliance with licensing rule 4116-2-b. The Chief
4

Administrator failed to properly complete and submit a valid
CWLM corrective action plan for the 2024 Interim Review.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the license be modified to a Second Provisional license.
